content.title: Antiplatelet Therapy in Vascular Disease
content.definition: Pharmacological inhibition of platelet aggregation to prevent arterial thrombosis in atherosclerotic vascular disease. Cornerstone of secondary prevention in peripheral arterial disease, coronary artery disease, and cerebrovascular disease.

key_concepts.description: Irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) → blocks thromboxane A2 synthesis → inhibits platelet aggregation. Effect lasts platelet lifespan (7-10 days). Dose: 75-325mg daily for vascular disease
P2Y12 ADP receptor antagonist; prodrug requiring CYP2C19 metabolism; irreversible inhibition. Alternative to aspirin or combined with aspirin (DAPT). Dose: 75mg daily
Aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor; indicated after coronary/peripheral stenting; typical duration 1-12 months depending on stent type and bleeding risk; increases bleeding but reduces thrombotic events
Direct-acting reversible P2Y12 inhibitor; faster onset than clopidogrel; not a prodrug (no CYP2C19 dependence). Dose: 90mg BID (or 60mg BID for PAD). Side effects: dyspnea, bradycardia
Potent irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor; faster, more predictable than clopidogrel; contraindicated in prior stroke/TIA; increased bleeding risk. Rarely used in PAD, mainly ACS
Protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1) antagonist; approved for PAD; added to standard antiplatelet therapy reduces MACE but increases bleeding; contraindicated in prior stroke
Phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor with antiplatelet and vasodilator effects; improves claudication distance; contraindicated in heart failure. Not a direct antiplatelet but often used in PAD
Single antiplatelet (aspirin or clopidogrel) recommended for symptomatic PAD; monotherapy preferred over DAPT for claudication; DAPT after peripheral intervention for 1-6 months
Low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5mg BID) + aspirin reduces MACE and MALE in stable CAD/PAD but increases bleeding; approved for vascular risk reduction
Continue aspirin for most vascular procedures; hold clopidogrel 5-7 days for open surgery; balance thrombotic risk vs bleeding for individual procedures
Laboratory or clinical failure of aspirin; may reflect noncompliance, drug interactions (NSAIDs), or pharmacogenomics; clinical significance debated

learning_objectives: Understand mechanisms of major antiplatelet agents
Select appropriate antiplatelet regimen for PAD
Know duration of DAPT after peripheral intervention
clinical_pearls: Aspirin or clopidogrel monotherapy for symptomatic PAD
Clopidogrel is the alternative if aspirin intolerant
DAPT 1-6 months after peripheral stent placement
Cilostazol improves claudication but contraindicated in CHF
Continue aspirin for most vascular surgeries
Rivaroxaban 2.5mg BID + aspirin = COMPASS regimen for high-risk PAD
common_mistakes: Using DAPT long-term for claudication (bleeding risk > benefit)
Prescribing cilostazol to heart failure patients
Holding aspirin for vascular surgery (usually continue)
Not recognizing drug interactions (PPIs with clopidogrel - controversial)
Using prasugrel in patients with prior stroke
